RT @air_hadoken: @bitovi @Smotko @brgrz However, on the plus side, 2015 CanJS code still looks familiar to devs who worked on JavascriptMVC…
@Smotko @brgrz I think 2.x is much better. A lot smoothed out. If custom elements aren't your thing, can.Control isn't going anywhere.
@Smotko @brgrz care to talk about it? I'd love to hear more in depth reasons justin@bitovi.com
@air_hadoken @Smotko @brgrz ah
Addressing some criticisms of the Longevity article: https://t.co/AbtcJI35jh
@air_hadoken @Smotko @brgrz which bugs?
@Smotko @brgrz in SemVer (http://t.co/2jREhc8v3p) any 1.x to 2.x will by definition introduce major changes, that's not a negative thing
@Smotko @brgrz the argument is not that new major features shouldn't be added that make building apps easier, its providing a clear upgrade
@Smotko @brgrz two years ago could have started with Backbone, then moved to Angular, then React, but that would be significantly more pain
@Smotko @brgrz techniques evolve and better ways appear over time, but there's always a clean upgrade path: http://t.co/3EF2R1WfzS

@steida pet peeve of mine saying there's a library/framework distinction. Frameworks are just "golden path" roads built on many libraries.
@steida @canjs's live binding templates r broken up into 4 libs that are useful on their own. Parser, target, nodeList and live
@steida @alesroubicek each part of canjs is useful on its own (until you get to its highest abstractions like can.Component)
@steida @alesroubicek you couldn't make it talk to a different stack
@steida @alesroubicek everything in there about evil is true of any large react app
@steida @alesroubicek then neither is canjs. What makes a framework?
